pageContext.title: Fave CEO Joel Neoh shares a day in his life
pageContext.content:
Day in the Life is a series where personalities in the Asian tech community recount what they do on a typical day. Read more from the series here.

I’m Joel Neoh, the founder of Groupon and KFit—now Fave. 

I don’t particularly have a daily routine, so I think this will be more of a week in the life.

Early mornings

I’m usually on flights in the early mornings. So, for example, out of five days this week, I’ll be on flights for four of them.

I usually pick the earliest times because I try to skip the heavy traffic going to and from the airport.

If I’m not flying—or even when I’m flying—I’ll usually prioritize my schedule for the day, as a lot of things tend to come in for me. I make sure to take time to do this so that I’m tackling needle-movers and connecting with critical people.

Late mornings

When I was first starting out, there was this book I read called Eat That Frog by Brian Tracy. It basically says to eat the biggest frog first—essentially getting the hardest tasks out of the way so the day progresses easier.

This time is usually for me to eat the frog. I think the hard things for me are handling real issues with customers, merchants, partners, team members, and employees.

So, I usually take anything that’s difficult for me or for the team first in the morning.

Lunchtime

If I’m not based with a team, usually I’ll catch up one-on-one with certain key leaders over lunch. Or, quite frequently, I’ll be powering through meetings. 

Sometimes I won’t be able to clear all the topics in the morning, so I’ll also power through in the office.

Afternoon

After lunch, I typically get into what I think of as “get shit done” moments. This is the time for unblocking.

Since decisions need to be made, anything that takes five to 15 minutes is what I’ll be focusing on—nothing beyond 15 minutes. If I need to spend more time on a particular item, I’ll usually postpone it to the night, after dinner. I don’t have time to sit down for half an hour trying to look through a deck, as it becomes a bottleneck for the product team.

I also sometimes have external meetings with partners.

Evening

I try to use dinner time to spend time with family. My family lives in Kuala Lumpur, so if I’m there, I try to have dinner with them because that’s the time I can connect or catch up.

After dinner, I’ll be doing the stuff that I postponed—the longer items on the list like looking through proposals, certain decks, or performance reviews. 

Before I sleep, I often reflect on the day: What are the things that went well? What are the things that didn’t go well? How can I be more broad? What are new ideas of thinking broadly about things?

Sometimes, I’ll also be on flights again since I usually take the first flight in or last flight out.

Weekends

If there’s important work over the weekend, I’ll allocate time to do it. But what I also do on weekends is to invest time in learning new skills.

I’m a big believer in parallel learning because whenever we learn new things in parallel, it opens up our brains and minds to new ways of thinking, building, and solving.

A year and a half ago, I started learning tennis from scratch with my coach. While training, I realized that the way my coach was teaching me was interesting. He wouldn’t tell me how to hit the ball, but he’d tell me how I’m hitting the ball.

So, I started applying this to certain people in my team, and the results were tremendous. I wouldn’t tell them what to do; I’d just tell them, “Hey, this is what you’re doing.” Then, I’ll get feedback on what they think about it.

Parallel learning over weekends works really well and helps reenergize the way I think about things and work.

***

As a founder, a lot of unexpected things get thrown your way every day, every week.

Overall, I think it’s about being situational and flexible. I think that’s what has worked for me at least. Doing this allows me to prioritize things in ways that matter the most at a certain point in time.

Being a founder is also about being comfortable with uncertainty. As much as we like things to happen in order, often times, it doesn’t.
